The University of Mississippi has a student body that is predominantly from Mississippi, with 55% of undergraduates and 60% overall being Mississippi residents. The university is also diverse, with 23% of students being minorities and international students coming from 90 different nations.

Johanna Braddy is an American actress. She played a main role in the web series 'Video Game High School' from 2012 to 2014. In 2015, she co-starred in the Lifetime series 'Unreal'. Currently, she is starring as Shelby Wyatt in the ABC thriller 'Quantico'.

Martin Van Buren, born Maarten van Buren in 1782, was the eighth U.S. President (1837-1841). A Democrat, he previously served as the eighth Vice President (1833-1837) and tenth Secretary of State (1829-1831) under Andrew Jackson. Van Buren was a key supporter and organizer for Jackson's 1828 election and briefly served as New York's Governor before resigning to become Jackson's Secretary of State. After resigning, Jackson appointed Van Buren as American minister to Britain in 1831.
Camden, New Jersey, is home to two universities: Rutgers University - Camden, founded in 1926 as the South Jersey Law School, and Cooper Medical School of Rowan University, established in 2012.

Michigan is a state in the Great Lakes and Midwestern regions of the U.S., the 10th most populous and 11th largest by area. It is unique in consisting of two peninsulas, making it a top state for recreational boating.

Penguin Books revolutionized publishing in the 1930s by introducing inexpensive paperbacks, sold for sixpence in high street stores like Woolworths, making high-quality fiction and non-fiction accessible to the mass market.

The film faced initial censorship issues due to its sensitive content, but Salama managed to adjust the script while maintaining its core theme of religious discrimination.

Chris Eubank Sr. (born 1966) and Chris Eubank Jr. (born 1989) are British professional boxers. Eubank Sr. boxed from 1985 to 1998. The CONCACAF Champions League is an annual football tournament for top clubs in North America, Central America, and the Caribbean, organized by CONCACAF since 1962.

Mary of Teck, later Queen Mary, was the mother of King George VI and grandmother of Queen Elizabeth II. Mary died in 1953, during the reign of her granddaughter, Queen Elizabeth II.

The NAACP Image Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Drama Series was first given in 1996. Omar Epps and Joe Morton have won this award the most times, each with three wins.

Human trafficking involves trading humans, primarily for forced labor, sexual slavery, or commercial sexual exploitation. The International Labour Organization (ILO) estimates that forced labor alone, a key aspect of human trafficking, generates $150 billion in annual profits. In 2014, 21.2 million people were victims of forced labor, with 68% exploited for labor, 22% sexually exploited, and 10% subjected to state-imposed forced labor.

Francis I, born Franz Stefan in 1708, was Holy Roman Emperor and Grand Duke of Tuscany, but his wife held the real power. Another Francis I, born in 1494, was the first King of France from the House of Valois, ruling from 1515 to 1547. Known as "Francis of the Large Nose" and "Knight-King," he fought against his rival Charles V but later formed a controversial Franco-Ottoman alliance with Muslim sultan Suleiman the Magnificent. The Italian War of 1536-1538 was a conflict between Francis I and Charles V.

Peking University, established in 1898 as the Imperial University of Peking, is a major research university in Beijing and a member of the C9 League. It is the first modern national university in China and is consistently ranked as the top higher learning institution in mainland China.

The White House Press Secretary is a senior official who serves as the spokesperson for the U.S. President and administration. Appointed by the President, they do not require Senate confirmation. Their primary role is to communicate with the media and public about the President, senior executives, and policies.

Kentucky, nicknamed the "Bluegrass State" for its lush, bluegrass-covered pastures, is known for its central Bluegrass Region, which includes Louisville and Lexington. Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event held from 1983 to 2000 by the National Wrestling Alliance (NWA) and later World Championship Wrestling (WCW). It was originally broadcast via closed-circuit television and later via pay-per-view. In 1987, the WWF scheduled a competing pay-per-view, Survivor Series, on Thanksgiving night, leading to Starrcade's switch to pay-per-view. The event was known for its violence, with the 1985 edition featuring an "I Quit" match between Tully Blanchard and Magnum T.A. that was later rated TV-MA due to its content. The 1997 Starrcade was the fifteenth annual event.

Benjamin Paul Ballance-Drew, known as Plan B or Ben Drew, is a British hip hop artist, actor, and filmmaker.

"A floppy disk, also known as a diskette, is a type of disk storage composed of a thin, flexible magnetic storage medium sealed in a rectangular plastic enclosure lined with fabric to remove dust particles."

Guatemala experienced chronic instability and civil strife from the mid to late 19th century. A bloody civil war was fought from 1960 to 1996 between the US-backed government and leftist rebels, with genocidal massacres of the Maya population committed by the military.
Forceps are a handheld, hinged instrument used for grasping and holding objects.
The Closer began its final, seventh season on Monday, July 11, 2011, after its sixth season was the highest-rated drama on cable.

Dr. Jack Shephard is the protagonist of the ABC television series "Lost," played by Matthew Fox. The show aired from 2004 to 2010, spanning six seasons with 121 episodes. The first season attracted an average of 16 million viewers per episode.

Matthew McConaughey, born in 1969, is an American actor known for his dramatic roles since 2011. Notable films include "The Lincoln Lawyer", "Bernie", "Killer Joe", "The Paperboy", "Mud", "Magic Mike", "The Wolf of Wall Street", "Dallas Buyers Club", "Interstellar", "The Sea of Trees", and "Free State of Jones". In "Mud" (2012), he starred alongside Tye Sheridan, Jacob Lofland, Sam Shepard, and Reese Witherspoon.

Robert Palmer, a renowned writer, is best known for his books like "Deep Blues," his music journalism for the New York Times and Rolling Stone, his work producing blues recordings and the soundtrack of the film "Deep Blues," and his clarinet playing in the 1960s band the Insect Trust.

James Lincoln Borglum (1912-1986) was an American sculptor, photographer, author, and engineer. He is best known for completing the Mount Rushmore National Memorial after his father, Gutzon Borglum, who led the project from 1927 to 1941, passed away in 1941.

The 100 is a TV series that follows a group of ten young people from a space habitat called "The Ark" as they return to Earth after a nuclear apocalypse. The main characters include Clarke Griffin, Bellamy Blake, Octavia Blake, Jasper Jordan, Monty Green, Raven Reyes, Finn Collins, John Murphy, and Wells Jaha. The series also focuses on Dr. Abby Griffin, Clarke's mother, Marcus Kane, a council member on the Ark, and Thelonious Jaha, the Chancellor of the Ark and Wells' father.
The Concert for Bangladesh was a pioneering humanitarian aid project that successfully raised awareness and funds, serving as a model for future events like Live Aid.
Mani Ratnam, an influential Indian filmmaker, revolutionized the Tamil film industry and transformed Indian cinema.

The Freeport Doctrine was a position articulated by Stephen A. Douglas during the second of the Lincoln-Douglas debates, held in Freeport, Illinois on August 27, 1858. This debate was part of a series of seven debates between Abraham Lincoln and Stephen Douglas, both candidates for the U.S. Senate from Illinois. The debates, particularly those in Freeport, Quincy, and Alton, attracted large crowds from neighboring states due to the significant national interest in the issue of slavery.

"Easy A" is a 2010 American teen comedy film directed by Will Gluck, written by Bert V. Royal, and starring Emma Stone. The film also features Stanley Tucci, Patricia Clarkson, Thomas Haden Church, Dan Byrd, Amanda Bynes, Penn Badgley, Cam Gigandet, Lisa Kudrow, and Aly Michalka.

Anne Rice, born Howard Allen Frances O'Brien, is an American author known for gothic fiction, Christian literature, and erotica. She started her career with 'Interview with the Vampire' in 1976 and gained more critical and reader acclaim in the 1980s. She was married to Stan Rice for 41 years until his death in 2002.

Camden is a city in Camden County, New Jersey, with a population of 77,344 as of the 2010 Census, making it the 12th most populous municipality in the state. At the start of the 20th century, its population was primarily composed of European immigrants.
Bret Easton Ellis wrote the screenplay for 'The Canyons', a 2013 American erotic thriller-drama film directed by Paul Schrader.
The Lincoln-Douglas Debates were a series of seven debates in 1858 between Abraham Lincoln (Republican candidate for U.S. Senate) and Stephen Douglas (incumbent Democratic Senator) in Illinois.
"Homer, the ancient Greek author, wrote the Iliad and the Odyssey, two central epic poems in Greek literature. Joe R. Lansdale, an American author, wrote 'The Thicket', a mystery/suspense novel."
Christopher Scott Kyle, a former U.S. Navy SEAL sniper, was murdered by Eddie Ray Routh at a shooting range in Texas on February 2, 2013.

Audioslave was a four-piece rock band formed in 2001, consisting of Soundgarden's Chris Cornell (lead vocals, rhythm guitar) and former Rage Against the Machine members Tom Morello (lead guitar), Tim Commerford (bass, backing vocals), and Brad Wilk (drums). Brad Wilk, known for his work in Rage Against the Machine and Audioslave, later joined Prophets of Rage with Commerford and Morello. Rage Against the Machine, formed in 1991, featured Zack de la Rocha (lead vocals), Tim Commerford (bass, backing vocals), Tom Morello (guitar), and Brad Wilk (drums).

Janelle Monáe Robinson, born December 1, 1985, is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model. She is signed to her own imprint, Wondaland Arts Society, and Atlantic Records. Monáe's debut studio album, "The ArchAndroid," a concept album sequel to her first EP, was released in 2010 and received critical acclaim.
"Winter's Tale is a 1983 novel written by Mark Helprin."

Lake Providence is a town in northeastern Louisiana, serving as the parish seat of East Carroll Parish. It is home to the University of Mississippi, with approximately 55% of its undergraduate students and 60% overall hailing from Mississippi. The university's student body is diverse, with 23% being minorities and international students representing 90 nations.
"Flaked" was renewed for a six-episode second season in July 2016, set to premiere on June 2, 2017.

Aaron Burr served in the New York State Assembly (1784-1785, 1798-1799), was New York State Attorney General (1789-1791), U.S. Senator from New York (1791-1797), and reached his peak as Vice President.

The Soyuz rocket was commissioned in the 1960s by the Korolyov Design Bureau (now RKK Energia) for the Soviet human spaceflight program. It first conducted 8 unmanned test flights, followed by 19 manned launches. The Soyuz spacecraft, designed for this program, remains in use today and succeeded the Voskhod spacecraft. It was initially part of the Soviet manned lunar programs.
Steve Ditko studied under Batman artist Jerry Robinson at the Cartoonist and Illustrators School in New York City.

Rage Against the Machine, a rap metal band, released their fourth studio album 'Renegades' in 2000. The band broke up in 1999 due to tensions, with vocalist Zack de la Rocha leaving to pursue a solo career. The remaining members formed Audioslave with Chris Cornell in 2001, releasing three albums before disbanding in 2007. Rage Against the Machine reunited in 2007 and performed together for the first time in seven years at Coachella that April.

The S&P BSE SENSEX is a market-weighted stock market index comprising 30 well-established and financially sound companies listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange. Tata Motors is one of the constituents of this index, being listed on both the Bombay Stock Exchange and the National Stock Exchange of India, as well as the New York Stock Exchange.

Vietnam, officially the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, is the easternmost country on the Indochina Peninsula in Southeast Asia. It is the 14th-most-populous country in the world and the 9th-most-populous in Asia, with an estimated 92.7 million inhabitants. Vietnam is bordered by China, Laos, Cambodia, Thailand, and several other countries across the South China Sea. Since 2000, Vietnam's economic growth rate has been among the highest in the world, and in 2011, it had the highest Global Growth Generators Index among 11 major economies. Vietnam is one of the world's four remaining one-party socialist states officially espousing communism.
"Dreamer" is a 2005 American sports drama film written and directed by John Gatins in his directorial debut.

Bhagat Singh, born on 23 March 1931, was an Indian socialist revolutionary who gained fame for his dramatic acts of violence against British rule in India. Despite his execution at the age of 23, he became a folk hero of the Indian independence movement.
Aparshakti Khurana made his Bollywood debut with the 2016 film 'Dangal', directed by Nitesh Tiwari.

James VI of Scotland became James I of England in 1603, ruling both kingdoms until his death in 1625. Despite personal union, each kingdom maintained its own parliament and laws. James advocated for a single parliament but faced challenges with the English Parliament during his reign.

Danielle Cormack, born on December 26, 1970, is a New Zealand actress known for her roles in various TV series and films. She started her career in the soap opera "Shortland Street" and gained international recognition for playing Ephiny in "Xena: Warrior Princess". Other notable roles include Cynthia Ross in "The Cult", Shota in "Legend of the Seeker", and Kate Leigh in "Underbelly: Razor". She portrayed Bea Smith in the prison drama "Wentworth" for four years until 2016.
Rob Sheridan is an American graphic designer, director, and photographer, born on October 11, 1979, who is best known for his extensive work with the band Nine Inch Nails.

David Spade is an American actor and comedian known for his roles in films like "Tommy Boy," "Black Sheep," "Joe Dirt," and "Grown Ups." He co-wrote and starred in "Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser," a 2015 comedy film directed by Fred Wolf.
Angela Bassett is an American actress born on August 16, 1958.

"Artpop, Lady Gaga's album, received mixed reviews but was commercially successful. It debuted at number one on the US Billboard 200, selling 258,000 copies in its first week, becoming her second consecutive number-one album. It sold 757,000 copies in total and was the ninth best-selling album of 2013 worldwide with 2.3 million copies."
John Frusciante's fifth and final album with the Red Hot Chili Peppers, "Stadium Arcadium," was released in 2006. This album marked his last with the band before his departure in 2009.

Margaret Thatcher, as Prime Minister, implemented policies known as Thatcherism, which remain controversial and debated. She is widely regarded as one of the most influential politicians in British history.

"Duff McKagan, born February 5, 1964, is an American musician, singer, songwriter, and author. Apart from his musical career, he has established himself as a writer, contributing weekly columns on diverse topics to SeattleWeekly.com, Playboy.com, and ESPN.com."
Tom Baker, an English actor, is known for his acting roles and has also narrated various media including commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.

Valencia is the capital of the Valencian Community, Spain's third largest city and metropolitan area, with approximately 800,000 inhabitants in the city proper and between 1.7 to 2.5 million in the metropolitan area.
Buffy Summers was portrayed by Kristy Swanson in the 1992 film "Buffy the Vampire Slayer," and later by Sarah Michelle Gellar in the television series that aired from 1997 to 2003.
"Make It or Break It" ended on May 14, 2012, with its third season being the final one.

Speech recognition is a field that combines linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering to enable computers to understand and translate spoken language into text. Its applications include voice user interfaces, call routing, appliance control, search, data entry, document preparation, speech-to-text processing, and aircraft control. The field has seen significant advancements, with major tech companies like Google, Microsoft, IBM, and others adopting deep learning methods for speech recognition systems.

Richard Alf, born on January 26, 1952, and passed away on January 4, 2012, was an American businessman and former comic book store owner. He co-founded the San Diego Comic-Con International in 1970, serving as its chairman. Initially named the Golden State Comic Book Convention, it was later known as the San Diego Comic Book Convention.
"Fist of Legend is a remake of the 1972 film 'Fist of Fury', with Bruce Lee in the lead role."

Rory McIlroy, the world number three, shot a 67 to move to 15 under par, tied for third place in the Turkish Airlines Open. He had an eagle on the 12th and is bidding for his first title since May. McIlroy, who returned from an ankle injury, is targeting a third Race to Dubai title in four years and leads Danny Willett by 271,214 points with three events remaining.

**Summary:**

- Sheikh Ali Salman, leader of al-Wefaq, the main opposition society in Bahrain, calls for meaningful national dialogue with concrete solutions from the government.
- He welcomes the agreed dialogue process but acknowledges young protesters' distrust in opposition parties and the royal family.
- Salman believes working with reformists like Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa is the way forward, citing a previous agreement on a seven-point plan for a constitutional monarchy.
- He hopes for stronger US and UK pressure on Bahrain to respect human rights and democratic practices, criticizing the UK's private urging of reform.
- Salman calls for the release of 13 opposition leaders and activists, emphasizing their importance in successful dialogue.
- He reiterates al-Wefaq's commitment to peaceful demonstrations despite the ban on public gatherings in Bahrain.

Christopher Hogwood, a prominent figure in the early-music movement, passed away at his Cambridge home after a several-month illness. He was a renowned conductor and keyboard player, known for founding the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973 and directing it across six continents for over three decades. The AAM produced over 200 CDs, including the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. Hogwood's influential work earned him various academic positions, including honorary professor at the University of Cambridge. He was remembered as a generous, clever, and genial man who was a great ambassador for historically informed music.

The passage reports a decrease in homicide cases in Scotland, with 57 victims recorded in the year to March 2016, the lowest number since 1976. Knives were the most common weapon used (51% of cases), and alcohol or drugs were involved in 31% of cases. The Justice Secretary emphasized the importance of continued efforts to reduce violent crime, while the Scottish Labour's justice spokeswoman expressed caution about the figures and raised concerns about increases in other types of crime.

Bournemouth (Cherries) lost 2-1 to Sunderland, their first defeat to the Black Cats this season. Bournemouth scored their first goal in three games but couldn't capitalize on their chances, losing despite playing against 10 men. Manager Eddie Howe expressed frustration at their lack of scoring despite creating numerous opportunities.

Mr. Abbott, Australia's former Prime Minister, believes the only way to prevent migrant deaths at sea is to "stop the boats," which is Australia's policy of detaining and processing migrants who arrive by boat. The New York Times criticized this policy as "brutal" and "inhumane," and warned European leaders against adopting similar policies. Mr. Abbott defended his stance, stating that stopping the boats has saved lives in Australia. He also sparked controversy by comparing the Islamic State (IS) to the Nazis, a comparison that was criticized by Australian Jewish groups.

Washington suspended talks with Russia over Syria due to Russia's failure to halt attacks on civilians in Aleppo. Russia and Syria have intensified airstrikes, including on hospitals, since a ceasefire ended two weeks ago. Hundreds of civilians, including children, have died, and 250,000 are trapped in eastern Aleppo. The US blamed Russia for the collapse of the truce and accused it of shifting blame. Russia regretted the US move and accused it of not fulfilling its own commitments. Despite the suspension, both sides agreed to maintain communication to avoid clashes.

**Summary:**

- A think tank, Policy Exchange, proposed selling high-value social homes when they become vacant to raise £4.5bn annually.
- This could fund the building of 80,000 to 170,000 social homes, potentially creating the largest social housing program since the 1970s.
- The proposal aims to reduce the social housing waiting list by around 500,000 people.
- Labour criticized the plan, arguing it would drive out low-income families from expensive areas and create segregated communities.
- The government supported the idea, stating councils should use their social housing stock efficiently.
- Policy Exchange estimates that selling expensive social housing could raise up to £159bn, with London alone having over £70bn worth of such housing.
- The proposal aims to help hard-working people live in nicer areas or bigger houses by freeing up more social housing.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, a 25-year-old from Swansea, died recently. Measles was suspected but not confirmed as the cause of death. He had recently been treated for asthma and developed a rash before his death. An inquest will be held, and further tests are pending. Since November, 83 people in Swansea have required hospital treatment for measles.
Vincent Hudson, 54, has been charged with a historical sexual offence against a boy under 16, which allegedly occurred in 2001. He will appear before North Cumbria Magistrates' Court.

Neil Aspin's Guiseley and Adam Lockwood's Gateshead drew 1-1 in a National League match. Guiseley scored first in the 15th minute through Jake Lawlor, but Gateshead equalized in the 62nd minute with a goal from Wes York. Both teams were unbeaten in their respective recent matches (Guiseley in 9, Gateshead in 5).

Bristol Sport Ltd, owners of Bristol City FC, have decided to redevelop two stands at their current stadium instead of building a new one at Ashton Vale. The project, approved by Bristol City Council, aims to increase capacity. Majority shareholder Steve Lansdown confirmed the start of work at a shareholder meeting, with plans to begin in May if no judicial review is filed by March.

Cuadrilla Resources has temporarily halted fracking operations in Lancashire due to a 1.5 magnitude tremor, the second such event in two months. The British Geological Survey (BGS) confirmed that the tremor was similar to one in April and occurred near the drilling site. Cuadrilla will analyze data from the BGS before deciding whether to resume operations. The process of fracking involves injecting pressurized water into rocks to release gas, which can cause earthquakes. The BGS is monitoring fracking as a precaution.

Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old Liverpool busker, was found guilty of one count of fraud after playing with a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner on his bagpipes in 2015, giving the impression he was collecting for charity. He was cleared of two other counts. Carpenter, who usually busks in a kilt and piper's regalia, claimed he was not collecting funds but paying tribute to the victims. He will be sentenced in January.

Ipswich Town defeated Queens Park Rangers 3-0 in a Championship match. Grant Ward scored the opener for Ipswich, followed by Luke Varney's goal after a mistake by QPR keeper Alex Smithies. Cole Skuse's long-range shot led to Tom Lawrence's goal. Ipswich could have scored more, with chances missed by Christophe Berra and Skuse. Rangers offered little in attack and had a late header hit the post. The win lifted Ipswich to 14th, above Rangers who slipped to 15th.

"Wells, 23, scored 373 runs in the T20 Blast last season, averaging 28.69 with a strike rate of 138.66. He praised the club's environment, created by the coaches, as one of 'elite performance' that motivates players."

The Reds, currently fifth in National Two South, secured a 29-12 victory over third-placed Chinnor, their second consecutive win. The team's front row and front five, led by Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey, and Craig Williams, made over 70 tackles, contributing significantly to the win. In their next eight games, the Reds will face seven teams below them in the table and league leaders Old Elthamians. Despite the win, coach Churcher believes there's still room for improvement and emphasizes the need to build on their recent performance to avoid wasting the progress made.

The police arrested 28-year-old Nazrul, also known as Nazu, a Bangladeshi citizen, for allegedly raping a 74-year-old nun. This arrest marks the sixth in the case, with eight suspects identified and two still untraced. All five previously arrested accused named Nazrul as the rapist. Police acted on a tip-off that Nazrul, who had fled to Bangladesh, was returning to Kolkata by train. In May, Milon Sarkar was arrested as the alleged gang leader, but his role in the case is unclear. The attack on the convent school in Ranaghat town on 14 March involved theft and ransacking before the nun was raped.

The interactive video, featuring Robert Opie, explores factors influencing UK consumer buying habits, such as the introduction of domestic freezers, washing powder, and cheaper imports. It also delves into shifts in ownership and ranking of top UK consumer brands. The video may not function on older browsers, and a non-interactive version is provided below.

**Summary:**

- Two elderly women in Scotland (Sandyhills and Stranraer) were targeted by scammers posing as BT technical support.
- The Sandyhills incident occurred on September 15, and the Stranraer incident seven days later.
- Scammers gained remote access to the victims' computers and stole money.
- PC Siobhan Pellett warns the public to be cautious when receiving cold calls offering to fix computer issues, especially when asked for banking details or account numbers.
- Banks and reputable businesses do not ask for such information over the phone.

Duffy, a 37-year-old former rugby player and Scotland assistant coach, has been appointed as the new head coach of Featherstone, a third-placed team in the Championship. He will lead the team in their final league game against Toulouse and has signed a one-year contract. Duffy previously coached Swinton Lions and has been praised for his efforts there. He has been replaced at Swinton by Stuart Littler.

The RNLI and coastguard responded to a call at Sker Beach, near Kenfig Nature Reserve, on Sunday at 12:50 GMT. A surfer was found unconscious on the wet sand with head injuries and was very cold. She was treated by a medic and then airlifted to the University Hospital of Wales in Cardiff.

At a UN conference in Geneva, representatives from over 160 countries agreed to dedicate a portion of the radio spectrum for a global flight tracking system. This decision aims to improve upon the current ground-based radar system, which leaves around 70% of the world's airspace uncovered. The new system, using automatic dependent surveillance-broadcast (ADS-B) transmissions, will enable real-time tracking of aircraft anywhere in the world. This move was prompted by the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 in 2014, which exposed weaknesses in the existing tracking system. The UN's aviation arm, ICAO, has set a deadline of November 2016 for adopting new tracking guidelines, including aircraft sending their position at least every 15 minutes.

Julian Hernandez, who went missing at age 5 in 2002, was found alive at 18 in Cleveland, living with his father Bobby Hernandez. Bobby Hernandez was arrested and charged with tampering with records to obtain a driver's license in 2012. Authorities suspected him around the time of Julian's disappearance. Julian's mother has been notified of his recovery.

**Summary:**

- A fire occurred on 2 March at a waste management site in Duncan Street, causing travel delays and requiring firefighters' presence for several days.
- The Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited's waste acceptance after the fire and later revoked their environmental permit, effective 7 August.
- The fire service found the site operators, Asset and Land Group, to be "broadly compliant" with fire safety law.
- The fire service raised concerns about potential impacts on residents, transport, and the environment, leading to joint visits with the EA.
- The cause of the fire remains unknown.

The Pro-Kremlin party A Just Russia proposed two bills in Russia's lower house, the Duma, linked to the situation in Ukraine's Crimea region. The first bill would allow Russia to accept territory from a neighboring state if its people express a desire to join Russia, even if the state is disintegrating. The second bill aims to speed up the process of issuing Russian passports to Ukrainians, particularly Russian-speakers, without requiring them to pay taxes, have previous residence in Russia, or give up their Ukrainian citizenship. The bill's preamble references "the 'brown threat'" from World War Two fascists. The plan was announced in Sevastopol, and several Russian MPs, including celebrities, have visited Crimea.

McLaren, a team with 182 Grand Prix wins and 12 drivers' titles, is currently struggling, aiming for the fourth row of the grid and decent points. This decline started in 2013 due to chassis design issues, and now Honda's power-unit is causing problems. Despite this, they have two world champions, including Fernando Alonso, who returned in 2015 to win a third title. McLaren's history is marked by cycles of triumph and decline, with previous periods of dominance and recent scandals. Ron Dennis, the team's long-time leader, believes they will soon return to success and break Mercedes' hegemony.

Thomas Baker, 44, was shot and killed outside Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool on 27 January. He had been at Phoenix Gym nearby. Three men, aged 29 and 32, were arrested and remain in custody. Police are searching for a silver VW Polo that fled the scene and are appealing for witnesses who may have seen something.

**Summary:**

- **Everyday Church Online**: Launched in the UK, offers virtual services every Sunday, with participants from 61 countries. It has a chat room like a church foyer and will stream a Star Wars-themed sermon, "The Hope Awakens," on Christmas.
- **Guardians of Ancora**: A free fantasy game for 8-11 year-olds, developed by Scripture Union. Players find Bible stories to light up the dark world of Ancora. It includes Christmas-themed quests about the birth of Jesus.
- **Viral.de's Digital Nativity**: A popular Facebook-style video telling the nativity story through status updates and social media posts, viewed nearly 6 million times.
- **Churches Advertising Network's Ad**: A modern nativity scene changing eras, viewed 250,000 times. It was rejected from cinemas for being "too religious."
- **Next Manga**: Offers Bible stories in Manga format, including "Manga Messiah" in 33 languages. They sent 25,000 Arabic copies to Syrian and Libyan refugees.
- **Social Media Usage**: Many Christian groups use platforms like Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram to

The eight-day hearing in Ebbw Vale is considering a proposal to take over 250 hectares (600 acres) of common land for a motorsport circuit. The backers, including Blaenau Gwent council, have offered around 320 hectares (800 acres) of replacement land. The inquiry has heard differing expert opinions on the environmental impact, with Natural Resources Wales expressing doubt about the equal value of the replacement land, while an ecology report by the developers claims there would be a net gain in biodiversity. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will make a recommendation, with the final decision resting with Welsh government ministers.

**Summary:**

- **Event:** Novaya Gazeta reported on 1 April that over 100 men were detained and at least three killed in Chechnya on suspicion of being homosexual.
- **Reactions:**
  - Chechen Muslim clerics met on 3 April, condemning the report as an insult to their faith and threatening "retribution" against those responsible.
  - Novaya Gazeta urged Russian authorities to protect journalists from potential reprisals.
  - Ramzan Kadyrov, Chechnya's leader, denied the allegations, stating there are no gay people in Chechnya.
  - The Russian LGBT Network confirmed the report's authenticity and detailed torture methods used against detainees.
- **Previous Incidents:** Two Novaya Gazeta reporters (Anna Politkovskaya and Natalia Estemirova) who investigated crimes in Chechnya were murdered, but the perpetrators remain unclear.
- **Current Actions:** The LGBT Network is helping people flee persecution, and if Russia fails to prosecute anyone, they plan to file a case at the International Criminal Court in The Hague.

**Summary:**

- **Investing Solutions (IS)** and **Fresh Start Housing (FSH)** are linked charities based in south London, with IS being set up in 2002 by Samir Patel, followed by FSH in 2010.
- IS is one of the largest recipients of housing benefit in the UK, making it highly profitable. It focuses on housing single homeless men over 35 in private accommodation.
- IS makes money by housing multiple unrelated people in one property and charging housing benefit for each person, rather than the property, resulting in higher total benefit payouts.
- A tenant, Nigel McCann, reported unsuitable living conditions in properties managed by IS, and became aware of its profitability.
- Wandsworth Council has paid IS over £2.1m in the past two years.
- Matt Downie of Crisis charity described the relationship between IS and FSH as "a new low" in poor practice.
- Samir Patel stated that FSH is independent and that the majority of rents are passed to private landlords.
- FSH has housed 788 homeless people since its founding, but did not disclose how many were housed with IS.
- The Department for

GB's final warm-up game before Eurobasket qualifiers resulted in a 75-71 loss to the Netherlands. Key points:
- Andrew Lawrence scored 14 points, Ben Gordon added 13.
- GB led for most of the first three quarters but was overhauled in the last 10 minutes.
- Coach Joe Prunty praised Ben Gordon's performance, despite missing out on London 2012.
- GB begins Eurobasket qualifiers with a game in Hungary, focusing on intensity on both ends of the floor.

**Summary:**

- Conor McGregor submitted a waiver to the Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) to use 8oz gloves in his boxing match against Floyd Mayweather.
- NAC rules require 10oz gloves for fights at 154 lbs, but waivers can be granted for 8oz gloves between 135 lbs and 147 lbs.
- The NAC will debate and decide on the glove weight on August 16, prioritizing fighter safety.
- McGregor has used 4oz gloves in his UFC career and welcomed Mayweather's suggestion of 8oz gloves.
- The NAC approved the fight after studying McGregor's skills, including his knockout of Nate Diaz, and considering his age, height, and reach advantages over Mayweather.
- McGregor hired boxing referee Joe Cortez to ensure familiarity with boxing rules.

**Summary:**

- **Key Figures:** Gavin Sherriff (54, London chief reporter for 32 years), Darryl Smith (43, feature writer for 25 years), Robin Esser (ex-Sunday Express editor with a 60-year career), Liz Hodgkinson (worked in the 1970s and 80s).
- **Fleet Street's History:** The first British daily newspaper was published here in 1702. At its peak, it was the hub of national and provincial newspapers, with nearly every major paper having an office within a half-mile radius.
- **Decline of Fleet Street:** Rupert Murdoch's move to Wapping in 1986 marked the beginning of the end. By 1988, most national newspapers had left, adopting new printing technologies and cheaper locations.
- **Legacy and Personal Reflections:** Despite its decline, Fleet Street remains an iconic symbol of British journalism. Reporters like Sherriff and Smith reflect on its history and their roles in its final days.

J.K. Rowling, author of the Harry Potter series, has faced criticism and abuse on Twitter due to her political views, including a donation to the No campaign in the Scottish independence referendum and support for the Labour party. She has blocked abusive users, including some who called her a "traitor", and has stood up to bullies on the platform. Despite the criticism, she finds comfort in the reminder that there are more decent people than not. The Scottish National Party (SNP) won 56 out of 59 seats in Scotland in the recent election, becoming the third largest party in the UK.

**Summary:**

- Children from deprived backgrounds are twice as likely to face police action than better-off children for the same crime.
- Poverty increases the likelihood of violence among both boys and girls.
- A history of police trouble is the strongest predictor of young people not being in education, employment, or training by age 18.
- Poorer young people are about five times more likely to be placed on statutory supervision.
- Extreme poverty increases the likelihood of being both victims and perpetrators of crime.
- Boys are three times more likely than girls to engage in violent acts, and girls from poorer backgrounds are twice as likely to be involved in violent crime.
- The study, the Edinburgh Study of Youth Transitions and Crime, tracked 4,300 young people since 1998.
- Despite overall crime rate reduction, crime remains concentrated in deprived communities with high health problems and unemployment.
- The Scottish government acknowledges poverty and inequalities, investing £296m to mitigate UK welfare cuts.

Mr. Karl Haugh (25) was stabbed to death in a laneway in Marian estate, Kilkee, early Sunday. Robbie Walsh (Island View, Kilrush) was charged with assault causing serious harm, remanded in custody. Two others arrested were released without charge. Walsh and two others allegedly entered Marian estate, looking for Haugh, and a fight ensued involving multiple individuals. Haugh received a fatal stab wound; knives and golf clubs were recovered. Walsh is next due in court on 14 August.

Phil Flanagan, a Sinn Féin MLA, tweeted in May 2014 that Tom Elliott, then an MP, had harassed and shot people while serving in the UDR. Elliott, who has a clear MOD record, was alerted to the tweet by Ann Travers and Arlene Foster. Flanagan deleted the tweet and later apologized, admitting his claim was untrue. The High Court has reserved judgement on compensation, and Elliott feels vindicated. Flanagan's insurance firm refused to cover him, leading to a separate court challenge.

Hawick Knitwear, established in 1874, has seen a significant increase in production and sales, currently employing over 230 staff. The company, under the leadership of Benny Hartop since November 2021, has boosted production to 9,500 sweaters per week, up from 7,500 last year. This growth is driven by strong demand for both their private label business and their own-brand range launched in January. Hawick Knitwear exports to multiple European countries and markets outside Europe, including the USA, Canada, Mexico, and Japan. The company's success is attributed to the dedication of its staff, with a positive outlook for the future.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, suffered serious head injuries when she was hit by a car driven by Brian Wright, 55, outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December. Wright admitted striking Blackburn but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving, claiming he was blinded by the setting sun. Blackburn is now in residential care. The trial is ongoing.

**Summary:**

- **Threat:** Growing Russian submarine activity, with around 60 submarines, including advanced, quiet, and highly skilled crews.
- **Exercise "Dynamic Mongoose":** NATO's anti-submarine warfare training involving 10 warships, helicopters, underwater drones, and a French maritime patrol aircraft.
- **Target:** German U-boat U33, acting as the unseen enemy.
- **British Vulnerability:** Lack of maritime patrol aircraft, making it difficult to detect and track submarines, particularly Russian ones near UK waters.
- **Implications:** Russia could potentially track the UK's nuclear deterrent undetected. The UK's defense and security review must address this gap.

**Summary:**

- Since July, South Sudan's violence has led to a refugee crisis, with 340,000 people fleeing to Uganda, more than any other country this year.
- Ethnic targeting, including killing and rape, is prevalent, with Dinka tribes targeting Equatorians and Nuer.
- Refugees, like Nelson Ladu Thomas and Otima Amos, have witnessed and experienced these atrocities, fleeing through the bush to safety.
- Uganda is coping with the influx, providing land and aid within 36 hours, but struggles with water supply and the sheer number of refugees (nearly a million).
- The UNHCR warns of a potential genocide and ethnic cleansing, urging international attention and intervention to stop the "massacre of civilians."

McKenzie, 38, will fight Jahmaine Smyle for the English super-middleweight title on November 12. He turned pro in 2013 after retiring from football in 2011. McKenzie has a record of 8 wins and 1 draw in 9 fights. He is the son of former champ Clinton McKenzie and is trained by his uncle, former three-time world champ Duke McKenzie.

The new Bridgwater Community Hospital, part of a £330m investment by the coalition for new NHS facilities, will have 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, and space for X-ray and mobile scanners. The current hospital, built in 1813, is outdated and in need of replacement. The total cost of the project is £33m, with the remaining balance to be paid by NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust. The new hospital aims to improve patient well-being and provide a one-stop shop for care. Planning permission is required for the proposed site at Bowers Lane, with completion targeted for autumn 2014.

A man was fatally shot outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace, Upperthorpe, near Sheffield city centre. He was found with a gunshot wound to his chest and later died in hospital. The victim was believed to be a member of a local family who were gathered for a celebration when the attack occurred. This shooting is one of several recent incidents in Sheffield, but it is the first in the Upperthorpe area.

**Summary:**

- **Actors:** Ukrainian Cyber Troops, Cyber Berkut, Anonymous International
- **Actions:**
  - Ukrainian Cyber Troops: Hacked Russian servers, disrupted rebel websites, monitored CCTV, printed pro-Ukrainian messages.
  - Cyber Berkut: Hacked Ukrainian government websites, disrupted vote-counting systems, leaked defense ministry data.
  - Anonymous International: Leaked Kremlin documents, published Russian fighter's letter.
- **Methods:** Distributed Denial-of-Service (DDoS) attacks, hacking, data leaks.
- **Motivations:**
  - Ukrainian Cyber Troops: Support Ukraine, disrupt separatist activities.
  - Cyber Berkut: Anti-Western, stop "genocide" in Eastern Ukraine.
  - Anonymous International: Expose Russian domestic affairs, cover Ukraine.

**Summary:**

- Tricia Marwick, the presiding officer, was emotional as veteran MSPs Duncan McNeil, Alex Salmond, and others bid farewell to the Scottish Parliament ahead of the 5 May election.
- Alex Salmond, former First Minister (2007-2014), delivered a valedictory address:
  - He reiterated his belief that Scotland is diverse, not divided.
  - He welcomed the transfer of powers to Holyrood but criticized the Scotland Bill for not fulfilling referendum campaign promises.
  - He expressed no regrets about leaving, stating, "There is no greater honour... than to be a member of this parliament."
- Duncan McNeil, a Scottish Labour backbencher, delivered a powerful final speech:
  - He warned Holyrood to learn from Westminster's committee system to ensure accountability and scrutiny.
  - He recalled former Labour MP Robin Cook's visit to Holyrood for lessons on reforming Westminster.
- Annabel Goldie, former Scottish Conservative MSP, also bid farewell, jokingly mentioning her interactions with Finance Secretary John Swinney.

The Older People's Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is conducting a review to assess the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales. She is gathering experiences from pensioners, their families, and friends to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. The review will consider factors like physical and psychological health, social relationships, and care home environment. The commissioner aims to highlight good care and address poor care, ensuring those responsible understand the realities of residential care. Care Forum Wales supports the review but expresses disappointment that care providers are not represented on the main advisory panel.

Harbro Group, based in Aberdeenshire, reported a £800,000 increase in pre-tax profit to £3.5m in the year ending June 2016, despite a £1m decrease in turnover to just over £100m. The company, which manufactures and supplies animal feeds and operates 19 Country Store retail outlets in Scotland, saw international sales grow in both Europe and new markets. Despite facing challenges in the agriculture industry and uncertainty due to Brexit, the company is confident in its position for future business challenges.

A man in his 70s was found dead in a house in Little Gaddesden, near Berkhamsted, on Saturday afternoon. A man in his 80s was hospitalized. Police are treating the death as murder and are urgently seeking 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin (also known as Ian John Baker) in connection with the offense. McLoughlin is described as white, 6ft tall, with greying hair, and was last seen wearing sunglasses, blue jeans, and a checked shirt. Police advise not to approach him and have urged anyone with information to contact them or Crimestoppers. Additional patrols have been conducted in the area to reassure residents.

The IMF's second-in-command, David Lipton, warned of global economic risks in a speech, citing a weakening baseline and a delicate juncture. This follows disappointing Chinese trade figures, with exports dropping by a quarter year-on-year. The IMF is set to lower its global growth forecast from 3.4% in its April update, impacting businesses and industries tied to China's growth.

**Summary:**

- The new Cowes ferry has faced numerous issues since its launch on 14 May, including breakdowns, running aground, and damage to cars.
- In response, the council has made the crossing free until 2 July to gather feedback and has ordered an audit review of the project.
- Local businesses, like Angie Booth's Valu-4-U, are struggling due to the ferry's problems, with Booth questioning if her business will survive.
- Compensation for businesses is under discussion, with transport councillor Ian Ward acknowledging potential issues but not labeling it a disaster.
- Ward attributes the problems to teething issues and seamanship, with electrical problems and groundings having been addressed.

A 32-year-old man died in a multi-vehicle crash on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott around 07:30 GMT on Thursday. A 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention. The road was closed between Thursley and Liphook for investigation until early evening.

**Summary:**

- Matching Models, an international temp agency, advertised for a personal assistant with specific physical attributes, including "brown long hair with b-c cup".
- The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) condemned the ad as "appalling, unlawful, and demeaning to women", and threatened legal action.
- Women's equality campaigners criticized the ad, stating it was outdated and likely illegal.
- The agency's founder, Nathalie Jansen, defended the practice, claiming clients value looks alongside skills.
- Another job ad sought a "sexy female driver" for a Knightsbridge-based businessman, further drawing criticism.
- Employment lawyer James Lynas deemed the ads "clearly unlawful", potentially discriminatory against older women and open to sex discrimination claims.
- The agency's website stated it understands the importance of attractive employees for first impressions, but EHRC chief executive Rebecca Hilsenrath argued that professional skills are more important.
- Under the 2010 Equality Act, it's illegal for employers to discriminate based on age, sexual orientation, disability, race, religion, or other protected characteristics.
- Jansen explained that clients' specific requests drive the job descriptions, but critics argue these practices are discrimin

**Summary:**

- A shooting incident occurred at a hostel attached to Pragati Residential School in Bangalore.
- The alleged gunman, Mahesh, an office assistant at the school, shot 18-year-old Gautami in the head, killing her, and injured another student, Sirisha.
- Mahesh was arrested on Wednesday after a manhunt and was remanded until 12 April.
- Incidents of gun crime at schools in India are rare.
- In 2007, a similar incident occurred at a school near Delhi.

Glaad's study found 278 LGBT characters across TV shows from June 2016 to May 2017, with transgender characters increasing from 7 to 16. However, 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters died or were killed off, including Poussey Washington and Bea Smith. Broadcast TV saw a record high of black characters, driven by shows like Empire, Luke Cage, and How to Get Away with Murder. Glaad's president noted progress but emphasized that numbers are only part of the story.

David Mackintosh, Conservative MP for Northampton South, announced he won't seek re-election amid controversy over a £10.25m loan to Northampton Town FC for stadium development, which is now missing and under police investigation. He had faced opposition within his local party and denied any wrongdoing.

Roy Oliver, a 37-year-old police officer, shot and killed 15-year-old Jordan Edwards in Balch Springs, Texas, in April. Oliver was fired for policy violations and later charged with murder and four counts of aggravated assault. The shooting occurred after police responded to a party with underage drinking; Oliver fired into a car full of teenagers, including Edwards, as they left. Initial police claims that the car reversed towards Oliver were discredited by video footage. Oliver faces 5 to 99 years in prison if convicted. He is currently out on bail. This is the first murder indictment against a police officer in Dallas County since 1973.

**Summary:**

- Melania Trump and Barron will move to Washington "very soon" after Barron finishes school, but no specific date has been given.
- The decision has sparked criticism, with some viewing it as disrespectful to the symbolism of the First Family residing in the White House.
- Only two other First Ladies in U.S. history did not live in the White House: Martha Washington and Anna Harrison.
- Some supporters understand Melania's decision, citing her focus on Barron's education and well-being.
- Historically, some First Ladies and their children have delayed moving into the White House or lived elsewhere part-time due to school or personal reasons.
- Melania has indicated that Barron will be her top priority, suggesting she may not take on a full-time role as First Lady.
- The role of the First Lady is ceremonial, involving hosting duties and often supporting causes. Melania has hinted at tackling cyber-bullying.
- There's precedent for family members, like Chelsea Clinton, taking on some First Lady duties. The White House can be adapted to fit the family's needs.

The 72-year-old man died in Inverness on 27 October. Police Scotland's initial response to his call is being investigated by the Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc), Kate Frame, at the instruction of the Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service (COPFS). The investigation's findings will be reported to the COPFS.

The Met Office issued a yellow wind warning for parts of Wales and northwest England, forecasting gusts up to 75mph (120kmph), particularly west of mountains. The easterly wind direction could exacerbate impacts. Disruptions to travel on roads and at sea were expected in Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion, and Powys. A tree fell on Telford Road in Menai Bridge due to overnight gusts, closing the road for most of Monday.

The Giants and Panthers played a close game, with the Giants opening the scoring and the Panthers equalizing twice. The Giants then took a 4-2 lead, but Nottingham scored one back. The teams will meet again on Saturday. Nottingham leads the league with 28 points, followed by Sheffield Steelers with 27 and Belfast with 25.

**Summary:**

- Lewis Hamilton, starting from the back, had a difficult race with a broken front wing on lap one and five pit stops.
- He faces a 36-point deficit to teammate Nico Rosberg in the remaining 18 races.
- Sebastian Vettel finished second despite colliding with Kimi Raikkonen on the first lap, damaging both cars.
- Raikkonen finished fifth, passing Hamilton in the closing stages.
- The race was incident-packed, with multiple collisions on the first lap leading to a safety car on lap four.
- Hamilton's car was damaged in an incident with Felipe Nasr, affecting his performance.
- Rosberg won the race, extending his championship lead.
- Hamilton will need to overcome a significant points deficit to prevent Rosberg from winning the title.

Thomas Hitzlsperger, a prominent German footballer, publicly revealed his homosexuality in an interview with Die Zeit, aiming to spark discussion on a previously ignored topic in German football. His announcement was met with widespread support from former teammates, football administrators, and public figures, including Lukas Podolski, Arne Friedrich, Theo Zwanziger, Reinhard Rauball, Gary Lineker, Joey Barton, John Amaechi, and Bayern Munich. Hitzlsperger's announcement is considered a significant step in combating homophobia in football, with German Chancellor Angela Merkel's spokesman and openly gay politician Volker Beck also expressing praise and hope for further openness.

Sidwell, 34, has played 32 Championship games this season, helping Brighton secure promotion to the Premier League after 34 years. His contract expires at season's end, but he hopes to sign a new deal to help Brighton stay in the top flight. Brighton is currently leading the Championship with a four-point advantage, aiming to win the league title in the final two matches. Sidwell previously played for several Premier League clubs and believes he deserves another chance at the top level.

**Summary:**

- Blackpool scored first after 12 minutes through Jamille Matt, assisted by Nathan Delfouneso.
- Colchester equalized in the 17th minute from a corner, with Kurtis Guthrie scoring.
- Blackpool's goalkeeper, Sam Slocombe, made several impressive saves to keep the score level.
- Colchester finished the game with 10 men after substitute Sean Murray was sent off for a bad tackle in injury time.
- The match ended in a 1-1 draw.

"Reid, a 29-year-old footballer, played 37 games for Coventry last season when they were relegated. He has previously played for Charlton, Bradford, and Preston. He could debut for Colchester United against Aston Villa in the EFL Cup on Wednesday. Colchester's season began with a 3-1 loss to Accrington."

The passage discusses the creation of a permanent memorial for UK police officers and staff who have died in the line of duty over the past 250 years. The memorial, to be built at the National Memorial Arboretum in Staffordshire, was prompted by the murder of PC Keith Palmer outside the Houses of Parliament in March. The UK Police Memorial Trust aims to raise £1.5m towards the £4m needed, with the government committing £1m. The memorial will bear the names of over 1,400 officers and staff, and will include a brass screen with leaf shapes cut out, given to families as personal memorials. It is expected to be completed by 2019.

United leads the Premier League by 15 points with 8 games left after winning 1-0 at Sunderland. Ferguson focuses on upcoming games, mentioning the Manchester derby and aiming to surpass Chelsea's 95-point record. United has won 50 out of 54 points in their last 18 Premier League games. Ferguson plans to make changes for the FA Cup replay at Chelsea due to injuries, including potential returns for Giggs and Hernandez. United played well in the first half but faced a tough battle in the second half against Sunderland.

Google's chairman, Eric Schmidt, stated that the company pays the legally required amount of taxes, which was £10m in the UK between 2006 and 2011. He believes that tax payment is not optional and depends on the laws set by the government. He also suggested that if the UK changes its tax system, Google will comply. Meanwhile, Margaret Hodge, the head of the Parliamentary Public Accounts Committee, proposed a new committee to oversee the tax arrangements of major firms, including Google, which is criticized for minimizing UK taxes through its Irish operations. The EU agreed to tackle tax avoidance through automatic information exchange between tax authorities. Schmidt has previously advocated for international tax reform, suggesting that corporate taxes should be levied in the country where economic activity occurs.

NHS Improvement, the regulator, aims to reduce the NHS's £3.6bn annual agency staff spend by £1bn by the end of the financial year. A cap introduced in October has saved £600m so far, limiting hospitals' spending to 55% above normal shift rates for most staff. Despite progress, the NHS is still 10% short of its target, and it's unclear if spending on other pay areas has increased. NHS Improvement plans to publish league tables and details of high-earning agency staff to encourage better performance.

The Longford Town Centre, once a thriving commercial hub, now symbolizes Ireland's economic downturn. Local businesses, like Matt O'Brien's men's clothing shop, have struggled but are seeing a slow recovery. The opposition party, Fianna Fáil, criticizes the government's handling of the midlands, arguing for broadband improvement over water meter investment. The government counters with the planned Center Parcs development, which could employ around 1,000 people. However, local traders believe more can be done to boost business, such as addressing parking charges. Despite signs of recovery, the midlands still needs further economic support.

**Summary:**

- **Tournament Duration:** Starts with fixtures from 25 April to 22 May, with the final on 29 May.
- **Teams:** Eight teams participating, each playing against each other twice.
- **Qualification:** Top four teams qualify for play-offs.
- **Scoring & Wickets:**
  - Leading run-scorers: Warner (294), Kohli (267), De Villiers (249)
  - Most sixes: Warner (12), De Villiers (12), Kohli (8)
  - Highest score in an innings: De Kock (108), Warner (90*), Gambhir (90*)
  - Most wickets: McClenaghan (9), Kumar (8), Rahman (7)
- **England Players:** Eoin Morgan (Sunrisers Hyderabad), Jos Buttler (Mumbai Indians), Sam Billings (Delhi Daredevils), Kevin Pietersen (Rising Pune Supergiants)
- **Fixtures:** Listed from 25 April to 22 May, with play-offs from 24 to 29 May.

The Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs (DEFRA) reports a significant increase of 200 million plastic carrier bags since 2013, contributing to environmental issues as many cannot be recycled and end up in landfills and rivers. To tackle this, England will introduce a 5p charge for plastic bags from October, following the successful reduction in bag usage in Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland after similar charges were implemented. Environmental campaigners hope this measure will decrease plastic bag waste in England.

**Summary:**

- **Weather Event:** A severe windstorm hit Wales on Friday, causing significant disruptions.
- **Impacts:**
  - **Infrastructure:** Part of a school roof was damaged in Rhosgadfan, and major bridges had speed and lane restrictions.
  - **Power:** Hundreds of homes experienced power cuts.
  - **Transport:** Train delays occurred, and Irish Ferries cancelled sailings due to adverse weather conditions. The National Trust closed two sites due to expected high winds.
- **Wind Speeds:** Highest gusts were recorded at Mona on Anglesey.
- **Response:** Winds eased in the evening, leading to the lifting of restrictions on the A55 Britannia Bridge and the M48 Severn Bridge.
- **Future Forecast:** A blustery forecast for the Christmas weekend led to the postponement of Rhyl's Boxing Day Dip to Tuesday, 27 December.

Michael B. Jordan is excited to work with Ryan Coogler again in the upcoming film "Black Panther", set for release in February 2018. He will join Lupita Nyong'o and Chadwick Boseman in the movie. Jordan previously worked with Coogler in "Creed" and expressed enthusiasm about collaborating with Nyong'o for the first time.

The Alexandra Palace Theatre, founded in 1875, is planned to reopen in 2018 after repairs and refurbishment. It will host theatrical performances, cinema screenings, comedy, and live music. The BBC studios will also be repaired. The project, part of a larger east wing restoration, includes transforming the glazed east court into a public exhibition space. The total cost is £26.6m, with the Heritage Lottery Fund contributing £18.8m and Haringey Council £6.8m. The theatre, unused for decades, retains its original decor and stage machinery.

James Milner, a former Manchester City player, retired from international football at the age of 30. He played 61 times for England, including appearances at two World Cups and two European Championships, but only played 3 minutes at Euro 2016. Milner also holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player, with 46 caps. He scored his only international goal in a 5-0 win over Moldova during the 2014 World Cup qualifiers.

The Smith family's house in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, caught fire, destroying the house and killing their pets. The family escaped, thanks to David, the son, who noticed the flames and woke everyone up. The fire was caused by burning rubbish in the wood stove, and the fire alarm did not go off. The family escaped in their pajamas and has received community support with donations of clothes and other items. Marcy Smith is proud of her son David for saving the family.

The passage discusses a potential £200m takeover of West Ham United by an energy drinks company, following previous takeover rumors from Qatari and Chinese groups. David Sullivan and David Gold, who bought a majority stake in the club in 2010 for £105m, currently own more than 85% of West Ham. Sullivan had previously mentioned the possibility of selling a minority shareholding to clear debts, but they intended to pass on their ownership to their children.

The MTV Movie Awards, not the Oscars, featured fan-voted categories like best kiss and shirtless performance. Key winners included: The Fault in Our Stars (best movie), Shailene Woodley (best female performance, best kiss, Trailblazer Award), Bradley Cooper (best male performance), Channing Tatum (best comedic performance), and Meryl Streep (best villain). Kevin Hart brought his kids on stage, and Robert Downey Jr. was joined by fellow Avengers for the Generation Award. Summer blockbuster previews included Pitch Perfect 2, Trainwreck, and Avengers: Age of Ultron.

"Cammy Smith, a 21-year-old Scotland Under-21 player, was loaned to St Mirren from Dundee United. He has scored five goals this season and has a history of scoring for Aberdeen, with four goals in 89 appearances. St Mirren's manager, Jack Ross, considers Smith a 'brilliant acquisition' and a 'good fit' for the team, providing another attacking option. St Mirren, currently at the bottom of the Championship, will host Falkirk on Saturday."

Northumberland County Council is using Jetpatcher machines to repair 145 potholes daily for the next four months, as the weather is now warm enough. Additionally, extra staff will be repairing damaged drainage systems and clearing debris from gutters.

**Summary:**

- **Location & Time:** EnQuest's Thistle platform, off Shetland, in December 2016.
- **Incident:** Six Wood Group contractors were exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) while removing pipework.
- **Exposure:** The workers were exposed for hours without proper personal protective equipment (PPE), as they were initially told the area was clear.
- **Reactions:**
  - Steve Innes, the rigging supervisor, raised concerns and claimed EnQuest failed in its duty of care.
  - EnQuest and Wood Group took additional precautionary steps and conducted investigations.
  - Unite union criticized the treatment of the workers.
  - Health and Safety Executive (HSE) was not involved as the incident was not reportable under RIDDOR.
- **Health Impact:** Ongoing blood tests, but initial assessment suggested long-term harm was unlikely.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) in Singapore bought a bronze sculpture of Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari for $650,000 in 2007. The artwork was later found to have been stolen from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu, India. After discussions with the Indian government and a confession from the art dealer's manager, ACM decided to return the sculpture. The museum plans to seek legal compensation for the apparent fraud.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck 35km north of Lucca, Italy, at a depth of 15.5km, with its epicenter in Garfagnana. The tremor was felt in cities as far away as Milan and Florence, and caused several aftershocks. There were no immediate reports of injuries or damage, but phone lines and power supplies were down in the Garfagnana area, and schools were evacuated as a precaution. This is the second earthquake in the area in the past year, following two tremors in May 2014 that left more than 20 people dead. Italy is prone to earthquakes, with a deadly quake in L'Aquila in 2009 killing almost 300 people.

The passage describes a man named Austin Grant, 62, from Sheffield, who successfully grew a fruit in South Yorkshire's climate. Despite initial doubts, he was delighted to see the fruit, which is not yet ripe enough to eat, still attached to the plant.

**Summary:**

- **Release Delay:** Rockstar has delayed the release of the game (GTA V for PC) from 27 January to 24 March for additional testing and polish.
- **Reason for Delay:** The delay is to ensure the game meets the desired quality standards.
- **Positive News:** Online heists are coming to consoles before the PC release date.
- **PC Version Details:** Screenshots from the PC version have been released, promising high resolution (up to 4K) and high frame rate (60fps) gameplay, with support for up to triple monitor configurations.
- **Minimum PC Specifications:** Released to help players prepare their systems for the game.
- **Previous Success:** GTA V was a massive success upon its initial release, becoming the fastest-selling entertainment product ever.

The 76-year-old artist, Brian Simpson, won the £25,000 John Moores Painting Prize for his work 'Squint (19)'. The painting, depicting a leper squint in a medieval church, was described as "quite extraordinary" by judge Ansel Krut. Simpson, who has been shortlisted and longlisted for the prize before, plans to use the prize money for art materials. The John Moores Painting Prize, established in 1957, is one of Britain's oldest art awards, with previous winners including David Hockney and Peter Doig.

"Two pro-government Turkish newspapers, Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit, were attacked simultaneously by masked assailants in the early hours of Thursday, causing fires and shattering windows. No casualties were reported, but numerous spent bullet casings were found at both scenes. Police are investigating and no group has claimed responsibility yet."

The 24-year-old former Burton player, who was under contract with the Stags, has been signed by the Mariners on a free transfer. He spent the first half of the season on loan at Crawley, scoring three goals in 23 appearances. He will officially join the Mariners on 1 January, becoming Marcus Bignot's first signing for the club.

Arsène Wenger, Arsenal manager, praised Gareth Southgate's performance as England's interim manager and expressed confidence in his ability to secure the permanent role. Southgate, 46, has upcoming matches against Scotland and Spain to prove himself. Wenger also confirmed that Arsenal will offer a new contract to 21-year-old defender Hector Bellerin, despite interest from Barcelona and Manchester City. Additionally, Wenger updated that Aaron Ramsey, 25, will miss one or two more games due to a hamstring injury sustained in August.

The local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road fell from a cherry picker at around 13:45 GMT on Thursday, triggering a joint investigation by Lincolnshire Police and the Health and Safety Executive. The company is fully cooperating with the investigation.

The Transport Minister, Humza Yousaf, announced a new charter arrangement to resolve a long-standing dispute over seafarers' pay on two freight boats serving the Northern Isles. The RMT union had alleged that some workers were paid less than £4 an hour. The new arrangement will see the contracted out services return to operator Serco Northlink from next month, ensuring that all crew members will be paid at least the minimum wage. The dispute involved the freight vessels Hellier and Hildasay, which were operated by Seatruck under contract to Serco Northlink. Serco Northlink had previously offered to bridge the pay gap and backdate it, but Seatruck declined. The new arrangements are set to come into force early next month, subject to finalizing some financial and regulatory details.

Ken Dickie, 64, died six days after an incident at Rockley Park in Poole. Jamie Mitchell, 35, admitted intervening in an argument between Dickie and his mother, Samantha Mitchell, 57. The incident occurred after the couple, who were in a relationship, had been drinking at the park's bar. Mitchell pleaded guilty to common assault and both he and his mother admitted attempting to pervert the course of justice by lying about the incident. A jury found Mitchell guilty of manslaughter. Sentencing is set for 6 February.

Rod Temperton, a prolific British songwriter known as "The Invisible Man" for his low profile, passed away at 66 after a brief battle with cancer. He was famous for writing hit songs for Michael Jackson, including "Off The Wall," "Rock With You," and "Thriller," as well as Heatwave's "Boogie Nights." Temperton's songs have been recorded by various artists, and he won a Grammy Award and was nominated for two Oscars. He was known for his unique approach to songwriting, prioritizing love for the song first.

**Summary:**

- Swansea University researchers, along with international colleagues, discovered ancient earthworks (geoglyphs) in the Brazilian Amazon, possibly dating back 2,000 years.
- Over 450 large, geometric structures were found, hidden under bamboo-dominated rainforest until recent deforestation.
- The purpose of these sites remains unclear, but they're thought to have been used sporadically, perhaps as ritual gathering places.
- Soil analysis suggests the geoglyphs were built among taller vegetation, unlike visible structures like Maya pyramids.
- The research challenges the idea of pristine Amazonian forests before European contact, indicating human influence over 6,000 years.
- People likely managed forests by concentrating valuable tree species, creating a "prehistoric supermarket" of useful products.
- Some remaining Acre forests may still bear the legacy of these ancient agroforestry practices.

Nick Kyrgios, a 21-year-old Australian ranked 12th in the world, defeated Sam Querrey 6-4 6-4 in 53 minutes to advance to the second round of a tournament. Kyrgios, who won the Japan Open the previous Sunday, attributed his lack of usual vocal energy to fatigue from his recent success and travel, including a long commute to the tournament venue.

The Welsh government is considering expanding the HPV vaccination program to include boys, following advice from scientists, charities, and healthcare professionals. This is due to the increasing number of head and neck cancer cases, with three-quarters of those affected being men and the average age being 55. HPV is sexually transmitted and causes 5% of the global cancer burden. The Welsh government is awaiting advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before making a decision.

**Summary:**

- Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old boy from West Calder High School, passed away after battling a rare form of blood cancer called gamma delta T-cell lymphoma.
- He was known for his positive attitude and documented his journey on a Facebook page called "Jak's Journey," which gained over 28,000 Likes.
- Despite his illness, Jak attended his school prom for a brief period and met former Rangers captain Barry Ferguson.
- He received awards at the prom, including the Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award and the Kerry MacGregor Memorial Trophy for overcoming adversity.
- Jak's cancer spread throughout his body in January, and doctors decided against further treatment. He passed away shortly after.
- His family urged people to donate to Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research in his memory, and a charity football match was held in his honor.

Egypt won 1-0 against Uganda in a match where chances were scarce. The winning goal was scored by El Said in the 89th minute, assisted by Mohamed Salah. Uganda had a goal disallowed for offside. Egypt will play Ghana next, while Uganda is eliminated from the tournament. Ghana had already qualified after beating Mali 1-0 earlier in the day.

Lancashire County Council has chosen a site on the former Glenburn Sports College for a new railway station in Skelmersdale, following a study of three potential locations. The council aims to provide two direct trains to Liverpool per hour, in partnership with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council. The preferred site is large, has good highway access, and is well-connected to the town and surrounding area. The process of acquiring the land has begun. Skelmersdale, designated a new town in 1961, is one of the largest towns in the northwest without a railway station.
The plants were discovered in an elaborate grow house within a warehouse near Ashbourne on Saturday morning. A man in his late 40s was arrested at the scene.

A 28-year-old woman of Kurdish origin was severely injured in Hamelin, Germany, after being dragged by the neck through several streets by her 38-year-old ex-partner, also of Kurdish origin. She was rushed to a hospital and later transferred to a specialist clinic. The man turned himself in to authorities and is now in custody. The motive for the attack is still unknown, and police are seeking witnesses.

Women are as likely as men to ask for a pay rise, but are 25% less likely to receive one, according to a study by Cass Business School, the universities of Warwick and Wisconsin. The study, based on 4,600 full-time workers in Australia, found no evidence supporting the theory that women are less likely to ask for a raise due to fear of upsetting their boss or deviating from gender stereotypes. Instead, it suggests that there may be some form of discrimination against women. The study also found that women and men under 40 asked for and received pay rises at the same rate, indicating a change in negotiating behavior among younger generations.

Oxford City Council has been searching for a new burial site for many years but has not found a suitable location. Two existing cemeteries are expected to be full by 2018 and 2021. The council has explored various council-owned sites, but they have been discounted due to factors such as size, ground conditions, high water table, or restrictive covenants. After the remaining cemeteries are full, only the reopening of family plots, the use of reserved plots, and the interment of ashes will be possible. The last increase in burial space in Oxford was in 1932.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis (19-22 July) offers an augmented reality app for visitors. This app provides online content like videos and band interviews when users scan signs or posters. Notable acts include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. The festival director, Caroline Maclennan, aims to enhance visitor experience and global interaction through this new feature.

The 10-year-old horse Many Clouds, after winning the Cotswold Chase, collapsed and died due to a severe pulmonary haemorrhage, a rare condition that can occur in horses with no underlying health issues. Despite previous incidents of post-race ataxia and overheating, Many Clouds had shown no symptoms before the race or after winning. The British Horseracing Authority is committed to understanding and preventing such incidents.

Davina (formerly David Ayrton), now 34, was found guilty of raping a 15-year-old girl in a Portsmouth garage in 2004. Davina, who has learning difficulties and changed her name in 2012, will be sentenced on 4 March and is likely to be held in a male prison. The victim clearly recollected the events, despite having consumed alcohol, and reported the attack to a care home worker in 2014.

The Serbs, Novak Djokovic and Nenad Zimonjic, lost to the Brazilian duo Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in the men's doubles final at the Rio Olympics, with a score of 6-4, 6-4. This loss came a day after Djokovic's surprise defeat in the singles event to Juan Martin del Potro of Argentina. Djokovic, the world number one, had previously suffered a third-round loss at Wimbledon to American Sam Querrey. However, he bounced back to win his 30th Masters title in Toronto before the Olympics.

"Over 20 international competitors, including those from Scotland, England, Ireland, Europe, Canada, and the US, will participate in the Carrbridge event using only chainsaws to carve logs into animal and human shapes. Last year's winner, Pete Bowsher from Moffat, will defend his title and the Claymore Trophy."

Webb, a 27-year-old Wales international, has been out since September due to a serious foot injury sustained during a World Cup warm-up with Italy.
